The multi-CDKIs 1– 4 exhibited potent anticancer activities against breast, ovarian, and colon cancers which could be attributed to their pan-CDKs inhibitory activities
15–18
,
57 . The ability of these compounds to inhibit multi-CDKs could be attributed to the shared pharmacophoric groups between the four compounds, Figure 1. In addition, high sequence similarities were confirmed between different members in the CDK family. CDK-6 and CDK-9 have sequence similarity of 44% and 32% with CDK-2, respectively
6 . These similarities could also allow the CDK-2 inhibitors to target other members in the CDK family.
